bib_record.title: Measurement of neutron-capture cross section and capture gamma-ray spectrum of 105Pd(n,g)106Pd reaction.

free_txt: M.Igashira, T.Katabuchi.
School of Physics and Nuclear Energy
Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing, China  -
T.Wang.
M.Lee, G.Kim .
Research Center, Dong-nam Institute of
Radiological and Medical Sciences, Pusan, Korea -
M.Lee, Y.-R.Kang.
T.-I.Ro, Y.-R.Kang
3 MV Pelletron accelerator.
The energy calibrations of PH spectra were performed
with standard gamma-ray sources (137Cs, 22Na, 60Co) and
the background gamma-rays observed in the measurement
[40K: 1.461 MeV, 56Fe(nthermal,gamma)57Fe:7.638 MeV
(weighted average of 7.631 and 7.646 MeV gamma-rays)].
The capture yields were obtained by using a
pulse-height weighting technique with the weighting
function of the gamma-ray spectrometer and each of the
net capture gamma-ray pulse-height spectra.
The neutron-capture cross sections based on the
Hauser-Feshbach statistical model with the dominant
ingredients of level densities described by the
Gilbert-Cameron approach and the gamma-ray transmission
coefficients described by gamma-ray strength functions
were calculated.
For backgrounds: natural BG, the time-independent BG
due to neutrons, the time-dependent BG due to neutrons,
the tail of (p,gamma) peak.
Correction factors were evaluated considering
different effects coming from neutron self-shielding,
neutron multiple-scattering, gamma-ray scattering, and
gamma-ray absorption in the sample, from the dependence
of the gamma-ray detection efficiency on the gamma-ray
source position, from the impurities in the sample, and
from the dead time.
Large anti-Compton NaI(Tl) spectrometer of
15.2 cm diameter, 30.5 cm length, located 78.5 cm from
the sample at an angle of 125deg with respect to the
proton beam - to detect prompt gamma-rays emitted from
the sample. The long NaI(Tl) scintillator was centered
in hollow Compton-suppression NaI(Tl) detector of
33.0 cm outer diameter, 35.6 cm length.
Spectrometer was set in heavy shield: borated paraffin,
borated polyethylene, cadmium, 6LiH and potassium-free
lead.
The incident neutron energy spectra were
measured by a time-of-flight method with a 6Li-glass
scintillation detector of 102 mm diameter, 6.4 mm
thickness.
Small 6Li-glass scintillation detector (diameter 5.0mm,
thickness of 5.0 mm) located 30 cm from the 7Li
neutron-generation target served as a monitor of the
neutron generation.
3 MV Pelletron accelerator.
Metallic Li target. 1.5-ns bunched proton beam
of about 2.3 MeV energy. The pulse repetition rate
4 MHz, average current of the proton beam 6 microA.
Normalized incident neutron energy spectra is presented
Time-of-flight (TOF) to measure incident neutron
spectrum on capture sample.
Runs with and without the 105Pd sample (sample run and
blank run) and a run with a standard gold sample (gold
run) were made cyclically in each measurement.
PH spectra were measured for Pd-105 and Au.
The total measuring times for 105Pd was about 40 h;
for the gold - 9 h, the blank runs - 31 h.
Exp.procedure.
Isotopically enriched 105Pd metal disk of 15mm diameter
, about 0.68 mm thickness.
Gold disk of 15mm diameter, 1.0mm thickness was used as
a standard sample.
Sample              105Pd      197Au
Thickness,mm        0.675      1.0
The distance between the 7Li target and the sample was
12 cm.
Not explained.
Errors less 5.% .
Table 2 of J,JRN,200,235,2014 .
Measured data are compared with Empire-3.1
code calculation.
The capture gamma-ray spectra were derived by unfolding
the net capture gamma-ray PH spectra with the FERDOR
computer code and the response matrix of the gamma-ray
spectrometer.
Data are on Fig.6 of J,JRN,200,235,2014 .
Request for the data was sent 15.05.2014 to authors.
